questions.text: Which of the following is an apocrine gland?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sweat gland

 

Explanation:

The sweat gland is a type of apocrine gland. They are found in the axilla, perigenital area, and as ceruminous glands in the ear.

 

Apocrine Glands

Merocrine Glands (Option B)

Holocrine Glands (Option C)
  • The secretions are released along with the apical part of the cell membrane.
  • Blebs are formed.
  • Mammary gland: Modified sweat gland.
  • E.g: Breast, Sweat gland
  • Also called eccrine glands.
  • The secretion is released by exocytosis without losing a part of the secretory cell
  • Secretions are released without the loss of the cell membrane.
  • E.g: Salivary glands, Pancreas
  • The whole cell membrane is lost.
  • Becomes the sebum.
  • Entire cell organelles break down and become secretions.
  • Peripheral cells are intact.
  • E.g: Sebaceous gland

questions.text:
Match the following layer of skin with the cells present in it.


	
		
			
			1. Stratum Corneum
			
			
			a) Melanocytes
			
		
		
			
			2. Stratum Granulosum
			
			
			b) Keratin Squames
			
		
		
			
			3. Stratum Spinosum
			
			
			c) Keratohyalin granules
			
		
		
			
			4. Stratum Basale
			
			
			d) Langerhan cells
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

Explanation:

There are 5 layers of skin epithelium (epidermis). The cells present in these layers are:

  • Stratum Corneum:
    • Keratin Squames: Flattened, water-repellent cells composed of keratin.
  • Stratum Lucidum: Only seen in thick skin like palm and sole.
  • Stratum Granulosum:
    • Keratinocytes: Contain keratohyaline granules for keratin production.
  • Stratum Spinosum:
    • Prickle cell layer
    • Keratinocytes: Multilayered cells with desmosomes; involved in keratin synthesis.
    • Langerhan cells: Act as antigen presenting cells.
  • Stratum Basale:
    • Basal Keratinocytes: Cuboidal cells that proliferate and replenish upper layers.
    • Melanocytes: Produce melanin.
    • Merkel Cells: Touch receptors.
  • Dermis:
    • Fibroblasts: Produce collagen and elastin.
    • Sensory Nerve Endings: Detect stimuli.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the given image?

choices.text: GALT tissues are part of the Waldeyer ring.
Tonsils primarily produce secretory IgA to protect mucosal surfaces.
Tonsils are covered by stratified squamous epithelium that forms deep crypts.
Tonsils contain diffuse lymphoid tissue scattered in the lamina propria.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Tonsils are covered by stratified squamous epithelium that forms deep crypts.

 

Explanation:

The Tonsils are covered by stratified squamous epithelium that forms crypts, a key feature of tonsils.

Mucosa Associated Lymphoid Tissue (MALT)

Tonsils
  • Includes diffuse lymphoid cells and organized aggregates (e.g., tonsils, Peyer’s patches). (Option D)
  • The aggregations consist of lymphatic follicles (nodules) resembling lymph node structure, with possible germinal centers.
  • Between the nodules, diffuse lymphoid tissue, known as the parafollicular zone, is present.
  • Parts:
    • GALT: Found in the gastrointestinal tract (e.g., Peyer’s patches). (Option A)
    • BALT: Present in the bronchial tree.
    • Waldeyer Ring: Lymphoid tissue in the oropharynx.
  • Consists of T & B cells, Plasma cells and mast cells.
  • Antibody Production:
    • IgA: MALT produces IgA, which is the main antibody in mucosal areas, protects mucosal surfaces. (Option B)
    • IgG & IgM: Present in lamina propria.
    • IgE: Involved in allergic reactions.
  • Function:
    • Epithelium samples luminal antigens.
  • The palatine tonsils are part of Waldeyer's ring, along with the lingual, pharyngeal, and tubal tonsils.
  • They are covered by stratified squamous epithelium, which forms deep tonsillar crypts. (Option C)
  • Beneath the tonsil is a collagenous hemicapsule separating it from muscle.
  • The tonsillar tissue contains lymphoid follicles with germinal centers, similar to lymph nodes.
  • Bacteria and particles entering the crypts are passed to follicles, triggering immune responses.
  • Efferent lymphatics drain to deep cervical lymph nodes.
  • In the tubal tonsils, respiratory epithelium covers the surface instead of squamous epithelium.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the spleen is TRUE?

choices.text: White pulp occupies most of the spleen and contains a higher number of RBCs.
The red pulp parenchyma is supported by reticular fibers and contains sheathed capillaries.
B cells form an eccentric cylindrical sheath around a central artery, known as PALS.
The Perilymphoid zone contains numerous sinuses and abundant reticulin meshwork.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The red pulp parenchyma is supported by reticular fibers and contains sheathed capillaries.

 

Explanation:

Red pulp is supported by reticular fibers, and it contains capillaries that terminate as sheathed capillaries.

 

Spleen

  • The capsule is composed of collagen fibers.
  • Trabeculae function as partitions.
  • Red pulp occupies most of the area.
    • Red pulp contains a higher number of RBCs and also WBCs.
    • Red pulp features splenic sinusoids surrounded by splenic cords.
    • The red pulp parenchyma is made up of loose tissue supported by reticular fibers, interspersed with capillaries, which end as sheathed capillaries. (Option B)
    • The perilymphoid (Perifollicular) zone of red pulp, surrounding the white pulp, lacks sinuses, has a sparse reticulin meshwork, and contains red and white blood cells in proportions similar to those in blood. (Option D)
  • White pulp constitutes 5% - 20% of the total spleen mass. (Option A)
    • White pulp contains both T and B cells.
    • T cells form an eccentric cylindrical sheath around a central artery, mainly containing T helper cells, like PALS. (Option C)
    • B cells form follicles at the edge of the PALS, often showing germinal centers in younger individuals.
  • Splenic cords contain lymphoid macrophages, lymphocytes, and plasma cells (LMP cells).

questions.text: In a histological image of the thymus, which cell type is not present in the medulla?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Thymocytes

 

Explanation:

Thymocytes are primarily located in the cortex of the thymus and are not present in the medulla.

 

   

Parts of the Thymus:

  • Cortex:
    • The outer, more densely packed region of the thymus.
    • Filled with immature T cells (thymocytes), undergoing differentiation and maturation as they move towards the medulla.
    • The cortex contains thymic nurse cells that support the maturing thymocytes.
    • T cells express surface markers (like TCR, CD3, CD4, and CD8) during maturation.
    • Macrophages are present to phagocytose apoptotic T cells, which fail to mature properly.
  • Medulla:
    • The inner, less densely populated region.
    • Dominated by epithelial cells with pale-staining nuclei and large cytoplasm. (Option B)
    • Contains Hassall's corpuscles, concentric structures made of keratinized epithelial cells, involved in T cell regulation. (Option C)
    • Dendritic cells and macrophages in the medulla present self-antigens to maturing T cells, ensuring the elimination of self-reactive cells to prevent autoimmunity. (Option D)

Histology of the Thymus:

  • Epithelial Framework: Throughout the thymus, epithelial cells provide a structural scaffold for lymphocyte development and produce hormones like thymopoietin, which regulate T cell maturation and proliferation.
  • It is divided into lobules by connective tissue septa.
  • A protective blood-thymus barrier prevents antigens from entering, safeguarding T cell maturation.
  • With age, the thymus undergoes involution, where lymphoid tissue is replaced by fat, but it continues to produce mature T cells.

questions.text:
A pathologist is examining a lymph node biopsy.

Which of the following correctly identifies these structures?

choices.text: C- Capsule, E- Medulla, D- Cortex, A- Germinal centers
D- Capsule, E- Medulla, C- Cortex, A- Germinal centers
C- Capsule, A- Medulla, D- Cortex, E- Germinal centers
D- Capsule, A- Medulla, C- Cortex, E- Germinal centers

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) C- Capsule, A- Medulla, D- Cortex, E- Germinal centers

Explanation:

 

Parts of the Lymph Node

Structure

Description

Function

Capsule

- Outer covering of the lymph node

- Consists mainly of collagen fibers

- May contain some elastic fibers and smooth muscle

Provides structural support and contains the lymph node contents

Subcapsular sinus

- Located just beneath the capsule

- Receives afferent lymph vessels

Initial site for incoming lymph filtration

Cortex

- Outer zone with densely packed lymphocytes

- Contains lymphatic follicles/nodules

- Divided into superficial (nodular) and deep (paracortex) regions

- Site of B-lymphocyte activity (superficial)

- T-lymphocyte area (deep/paracortex)

Lymphatic follicles

- Rounded areas within the cortex

- Contain germinal centers when activated

Sites of B-lymphocyte proliferation and differentiation

Germinal centers

- Lightly stained central region of activated follicles

- Contain proliferating B-lymphocytes (centroblasts and centrocytes)

- Site of B-cell proliferation and selection

- Indicates an active immune response

Medulla

- Inner, lighter staining region

- Contains medullary cords and sinuses

- Houses plasma cells and macrophages

- Site of antibody production and lymph filtration

Hilum

- Concave region where blood vessels enter/exit

- Site where efferent lymph vessel leaves

Provides vascular and lymphatic connections

questions.text:
A histologist is examining three different cartilage samples.


	Sample A shows a homogeneous basophilic matrix with groups of chondrocytes in cell nests.
	Sample B contains numerous branching and anastomosing fibers forming a network.
	Sample C lacks perichondrium and has chondrocytes arranged in single rows or groups with numerous collagen bundles.


Which of the following correctly identifies these cartilage types?

choices.text: A - Elastic, B - Hyaline, C - Fibrocartilage
A - Hyaline, B - Elastic, C - Fibrocartilage
A - Fibrocartilage, B - Hyaline, C - Elastic
A - Hyaline, B - Fibrocartilage, C - Elastic

questions.solution:
The table mentions characteristics of various type of cartilage:

Types of Cartilage

Characteristic

Hyaline Cartilage (Most Common)

Elastic Cartilage

Fibrocartilage

Matrix appearance

Homogeneous, basophilic

Contains elastic fiber network

Numerous collagen bundles

Chondrocyte arrangement

Groups (cell nests/isogenous groups)

Similar to hyaline

Single rows or isogenous groups

Perichondrium

Present (except in articular cartilage)

Present

Absent

Main fiber type

Type II collagen

Elastic fibers

Type I (primarily) and Type II collagen

Main functions

Structural support, forms articular surfaces

Provides flexibility and resilience

Resists compression and shearing, shock absorption

Examples

Costal cartilage, tracheal rings, articular cartilage

Auricle, epiglottis, auditory tube

Intervertebral discs, menisci

questions.text:
Match the following types of collagen with their primary location:

 


	
		
			
			1. Found in cartilage (Hyaline and Elastic Cartilage)
			
			
			a. Type I collagen
			
		
		
			
			2. Major component of basement membranes
			
			
			b. Type II collagen
			
		
		
			
			3. Predominant in bowel and blood vessels
			
			
			c. Type III collagen
			
		
		
			
			4. Primary collagen in bones, tendons, and dermis
			
			
			d. Type IV collagen
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1-b, 2-d, 3-c, 4-a
Explanation:

Types of Collagen

Types of Collagen

Locations

Type I

Skin, tendon, sclera, bone, fascia, dermis

Type II

Vitreous humor of eye, intervertebral disc, cartilage (Hyaline and Elastic Cartilage)

Type III

Skin, blood vessels, bowel

Type IV

Basement membrane

questions.text:
A histologist is examining three different tissue samples.


	Sample A shows loosely arranged fibers with numerous cells and abundant ground substance.
	Sample B exhibits densely packed, parallel collagen bundles with elongated fibroblast nuclei.
	Sample C contains interwoven collagen fibers without a specific orientation.


Which of the following correctly matches the samples to their connective tissue types?

choices.text: A - Dense irregular, B - Loose connective, C - Dense regular
A - Loose connective, B - Dense regular, C - Dense irregular
A - Dense regular, B - Dense irregular, C - Loose connective
A - Loose connective, B - Dense irregular, C - Dense regular

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A - Loose connective, B - Dense regular, C - Dense irregular

Explanation:
The characteristics of various types of connective tissue is mentioned in the table below:

Types of Connective Tissue

Characteristic

Loose Connective Tissue

Dense Regular Connective Tissue

Dense Irregular Connective Tissue

Fiber arrangement

Loosely arranged

Densely packed, parallel arrangement

Densely packed, interwoven without specific orientation

Cell content

Numerous fibroblasts and macrophages

Few cells, mainly fibroblasts

Few cells (fibroblasts)

Ground substance

Abundant

Less in amount

Less in amount

Main function

Bind different tissues together, allow tissue movement

Provide strength and resistance to tensile forces

Provide strength in multiple directions

Examples

Endomysium, subperiosteal tissue, lamina propria of GIT, hypodermis, mesentery

Tendons, ligaments, deep fascia, aponeuroses, central tendon of diaphragm, dura mater

Dermis, CT sheath of muscle and nerves, capsules of glands, sclera, periosteum

 

 

Dense Regular Connective Tissue

questions.text: A pathologist is analyzing a biopsy sample from a patient with suspected connective tissue disorder. Upon staining, she observes fibers that appear black with silver impregnation and form a delicate network throughout the tissue. Which of the following best describes these fibers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Reticular fibers
Explanation:
Reticular fibers stain black with silver impregnation, which is a unique feature among connective tissue fibers. Also, reticular fibers anastomose and form networks.

Type of Connective Tissue Fibers

Characteristic

Collagen Fibers

Reticular Fibers

Elastic Fibers

Appearance under light microscope

- Wavy bundles

- White on naked eye

- Fine & anastomose to form network

- Thin, branching fibers

- Single

Staining characteristics

- Pink with H&E

- Blue with Masson's trichrome

- Red with Van Gieson

- Brown with Silver impregnation (Option A)

- Black with silver impregnation (specific)

- PAS positive

- Not visible with H&E

- Black with Verhoeff's stain

- Purple with orcein stain

Functions

- Tensile strength

- Structural support in lymphoid organs

- Component of basement membrane

- Elasticity and resilience

Locations

Widespread (e.g., dermis, tendons, ligaments)

Lymphoid organs, liver, kidney, bone marrow

Blood vessels, skin, lungs, elastic cartilage
 

 

 

 

Elastic fibers (Option B) are not typically stained with silver.

 

Smooth muscle fibers (Option D) are not relevant in this context, as they are not connective tissue fibers and do not have the characteristics described.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs correctly identifies the locations of Meissner's and Auerbach's plexus in the gastrointestinal tract, respectively?

choices.text: Between the circular and longitudinal muscle layers; Mucosa
Submucosa; Between the circular and longitudinal muscle layers
Between the circular and longitudinal muscle layers; Muscularis propri
Between serosa and longitudinal muscle layer; Between the submucosa and mucosa

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Submucosa; Between the circular and longitudinal muscle layers

Explanation:

Meissner's plexus (submucosal plexus) is located in the submucosa, while Auerbach's plexus (myenteric plexus) is located between the circular and longitudinal muscle layers of the muscularis propria.

  • The GI tract has four main layers: mucosa, submucosa, muscularis propria, and adventitia (serosa in peritoneal cavity).
  • Mucosa consists of:
    • Epithelium
    • Lamina propria
    • Muscularis mucosae (smooth muscle for local movements).
  • Submucosa is a layer of loose connective tissue with blood vessels, lymphatics, and nerves.
  • Muscularis propria has smooth muscle arranged in:
    • Inner circular layer
    • Outer longitudinal layer
    • Only stomach has an additional oblique layer.
  • Adventitia/Serosa is an outer layer of loose tissue, containing major vessels, nerves, and fat. The serosa is the visceral peritoneum present on the entire GIT except esophagus. Adventitia is present over the esophagus.
  • The enteric nervous system controls gut function with the Meissner (submucosal) plexus and Auerbach (myenteric) plexus.
    • Meissner's Plexus (Submucosal Plexus):
      • Located in the submucosa.
      • Contains parasympathetic ganglion cells and postganglionic sympathetic fibres.
      • Regulates mucosal glands and the smooth muscle of the muscularis mucosae.
    • Auerbach's Plexus (Myenteric Plexus):
      • Found between the circular and longitudinal muscle layers of the muscularis propria.
      • Contains larger clusters of parasympathetic ganglion cells.
      • Primarily controls smooth muscle contractions for peristalsis.

Fig. Auerbach plexus between two sets of muscles

questions.text:
Which two of the following statements about serous, mucinous, and mixed glands are correct?


	Serous glands produce a proteinaceous, enzyme-rich watery fluid, while mucinous glands secrete mucopolysaccharides that form a thick, viscous mucus.
	Cells of serous acini are triangular with centrally placed rounded nuclei, whereas cells of mucous acini are tall with flat nuclei at their bases.
	The pancreas is an example of a mixed gland, containing both serous and mucous secreting acini.
	The lumen of mucous acini is typically smaller than that of serous acini.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1 and 2 are correct

Explanation:

Serous gland

Mucous gland

Mixed gland
  • The secretions of serous glands are proteinaceous in nature. Cells secrete an enzyme-rich watery fluid.
  • Cells of serous acini are triangular with a rounded nucleus. Their nuclei are centrally placed.
  • E.g. pancreas.
  • In mucous glands, the secretion contains mucopolysaccharides. Cells secrete mucus which is a thick, viscous, and jelly-like protective lubricant known as mucin.
  • Cells of mucous acini are tall with flat nuclei at their bases.
  • The lumen of these acini is larger than the serous acini
  • E. g. goblet cells, and minor salivary glands of the tongue and palate.
  • The gland contains acini that secrete both mucus and serous secretions
  • E.g. submandibular and sublingual glands.

 

Fig: Histology of serous and mucinous glands

 

 

Fig: Histology of mixed glands

 

 

The other options B, C, and D are incorrect as they either misrepresent the functions or locations of these glands.

questions.text: Which of the following histological features is characteristic of Barrett's esophagus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Columnar epithelium with intestinal metaplasia

Explanation:

This is the hallmark of Barrett's esophagus, indicating a transformation from squamous to columnar epithelium due to chronic irritation.

  • Barrett's esophagus occurs when chronic reflux esophagitis causes the stratified squamous epithelium of the lower esophagus to be replaced by columnar epithelium.
  • Intestinal metaplasia is present, with columnar epithelium containing goblet cells at the lower esophagus.
  • The Z-line (where squamous transitions to columnar epithelium) is normally at the gastroesophageal junction but may shift up to 5 cm proximally, increasing the risk of esophageal cancer.
  • Parietal cells may be found in stomach biopsies, but goblet cells are not present in the stomach.

 

 

Fig: Histology picture of Barrett’s esophagus

 

 

Squamous cell hyperplasia (Option A): This is typically not a feature of Barrett's esophagus; rather, it refers to an increase in the number of squamous cells, which occurs in response to irritation.

Columnar epithelium with gastric metaplasia (Option C): Barrett’s esophagus specifically involves intestinal metaplasia, not gastric metaplasia. Intestinal metaplasia is defined by the presence of goblet cells.

Glandular adenomatous hyperplasia (Option D): While Barrett's esophagus can predispose to dysplasia and adenocarcinoma, the primary change is intestinal metaplasia, not hyperplasia of glandular structures.

questions.text: Which of the following structures in the human body is primarily lined by stratified squamous epithelium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Skin surface

Explanation:

  • The outer layer of the skin (epidermis) is composed of keratinized stratified squamous epithelium, providing a barrier against environmental damage.
  • It is characterized by multiple layers of cells, providing protection against abrasion, pathogens, and chemical exposure. It is particularly well-suited for areas subject to friction and wear.

There are seven openings that are divided into two categories which are lined by stratified squamous epithelium:

  • Four on the face:
    • Nasal cavity
    • Oral cavity
    • Eye
    • Ear
  • Three on the perineum:
    • Urethra
    • Vagina
    • Anal canal

Openings on the face

Description

Ear
  • The external ear cavity is lined by Stratified squamous epithelium
  • Middle ear cavity, lined by stratified cuboidal epithelium
  • The middle ear cavity and external ear cavity are separated by the tympanic membrane.
  • This tympanic membrane has two epitheliums:
    • Inner layer: Simple cuboidal epithelium
    • Outer layer: Stratified squamous epithelium

Eye
  • The first layer of the cornea is lined by stratified squamous epithelium

Nasal cavity
  • Lined by Stratified squamous epithelium.
  • It is lined with skin
  • The nasal vestibule is lined by the skin with hair: Stratified squamous epithelium

Oral cavity
  • It is discussed in 2 parts:
    • Tongue, hard palate
    • Tonsils, epiglottis

 

Openings of perineum

Description

Urethra
  • It is lined by stratified squamous epithelium
  • Only the tip of the male urethra is lined by stratified squamous epithelium
  • The rest of the male urethra is mostly lined by stratified columnar epithelium.

Vagina
  • The transition from stratified squamous epithelium occurs at the cervix, where the vaginal epithelium meets the simple columnar epithelium of the endocervix at the squamocolumnar junction.

Anal canal
  • Simple columnar epithelium above the pectinate line.
  • Non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium below the pectinate line.
  • Keratinized stratified squamous epithelium at the anal verge, continuous with the skin.

 

Lumen of the trachea (Option A): Lined by ciliated pseudostratified columnar epithelium, which helps trap and move particles.

 

Gastric lumen (Option C): Lined by simple columnar epithelium, which is specialized for secretion and absorption in the stomach.

 

Alveoli in the lungs (Option D) Lined by simple squamous epithelium, allowing for efficient gas exchange.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes transitional epithelium?

choices.text: It is specialized for absorption and secretion and consists of a single layer of cuboidal cells.
It is found in the skin and is composed of multiple layers of flat cells that provide a protective barrier.
It is found in the urinary bladder and ureters, consisting of multiple layers of cells that can stretch and change shape.
It lines the digestive tract and is characterized by a single layer of columnar cells that facilitate nutrient absorption.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It is found in the urinary bladder and ureters, consisting of multiple layers of cells that can stretch and change shape.

 

Explanation:

  • Transitional epithelium is found in the renal pelvis and calyces, the ureter, the urinary bladder, and prostatic urethra.
  • Because of this distribution, it is also called urothelium. This is a multilayered epithelium with four to six thick cells that can contract and expand as needed (stretchable epithelium).

Features of transitional epithelium:

  • Cells towards the lumen are very large and called umbrella-shaped cells (typical for transitional epithelium).
  • Each cell is attached to the basement membrane by a cytoplasmic extension. The basement membrane is straight.
  • It is exclusively located in the urinary system and is named as urothelium.
  • It is called transitional because it is transitional between stratified squamous and stratified columnar epithelia. It differs from stratified squamous epithelium in that the cells at the surface are not squamous.
  • The deepest cells are columnar or cuboidal. The middle layers are made up of polyhedral or pear-shaped cells.
  • The superficial cell layer, which lines the lumen, is the only fully differentiated layer of the epithelium. It provides an impenetrable barrier between the lumen and the bloodstream.

 

The epithelium most specialized for absorption and secretion would be simple columnar epithelium (Option A), which lines organs involved in these processes, such as the intestines and glands.

Transitional epithelium is not found in the skin; the skin is lined by stratified squamous epithelium (Option B).

The digestive tract (Option D)is lined by different types of epithelium depending on the region. Transitional epithelium is not found in the digestive tract; it is found in the urinary system.

questions.text: Which of the following locations contains pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Respiratory tract

 

Explanation:

The respiratory tract, including the trachea and bronchi, is lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium, which helps move mucus.

Stratified squamous epithelium

Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium
  • Multiple layers of cells undergo maturation from a cuboidal basal layer to a flattened surface layer.
  • Basal cells continuously divide and migrate to the surface where they become anucleate squames.
  • It is present in the regions which need protection
  • It is of two types
    • Stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium
    • Stratified squamous keratinized epithelium
  • Cilia are never present on true stratified epithelia.
  • True simple epithelium.
  • All cells rest on the basement membrane, but the nuclei are at varying levels, creating an illusion of multiple layers.
  • Cells exhibit polarity with nuclei mainly in the basal two-thirds.

Lines the oral cavity, pharynx, esophagus, anal canal, uterine cervix and vagina. (Options A, B, & D ruled out)
  • Respiratory epithelium in the respiratory tract. (Option C)
  • Cilia is present to move the mucus

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			1. Simple squamous epithelium
			
			
			a) Proximal convoluted tubule
			
		
		
			
			2. Simple cuboidal epithelium
			
			
			b) Gallbladder
			
		
		
			
			3. Simple columnar epithelium
			
			
			c) Femoral Endothelium
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1- c, 2-a, 3-b

Explanation:

Simple epithelia consist of a single layer of cells and are primarily found at interfaces where selective diffusion, absorption, and secretion occur. They are of three types.

 

Types of Simple epithelium

Description

Simple squamous epithelium
  • Pavemented epithelium
  • Flattened, irregularly shaped cells forming a continuous surface.
  • Lining surfaces of gas and fluid exchange
  • Lining pleural, pericardial, and peritoneal cavities to enable fluid exchange and reduce friction.
    • Peritoneum (mesothelium)
    • Vascular endothelium

 

Simple cuboidal epithelium
  • The cells are polygonal and nucleus is round located in the center of the cell.
  • Usually lines small ducts and tubules that have excretory, secretory or absorptive functions
    • Collecting tubules of the kidney
    • Small excretory ducts of the salivary glands and pancreas.
    • Microvilli- PCT of kidney

 

Simple columnar epithelium
  • Tall columnar cells with the nuclei being located in the middle of the cells.
  • Non-ciliated cells have secretory function whereas ciliated cells help in transport.
    • Non-ciliated- Gallbladder lining.
    • Microvilli- Small intestine
    • Surface cilia- Fallopian tube
    • Pseudostratification- Respiratory tract
    • Goblet cells- Small and large bowel
    • Stereocilia- Vas deferens

questions.text: Given below are two histological images 1 and 2, which of the following pairs accurately represents the tissues depicted?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1- Urinary Bladder; 2- Trachea

Explanation:

Trachea

Urinary Bladder
  • Epithelium: Lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium, goblet cells, serous cells, and basal cells (neuroendocrine and stem cells).
  • Ciliated columnar cells are more abundant in the lower trachea, while goblet and basal cells are more common in the upper trachea.
  • Lamina Propria: Loose, highly vascular connective tissue beneath the epithelium, becoming more condensed at deeper levels with fibroelastic tissue.
  • Submucosa: Contains seromucinous glands that decrease in number toward the lower trachea; serous cells stain strongly, mucous cells stain poorly with H&E.
  • Hyaline cartilage rings support the trachea, with the submucosa merging into the perichondrium or fibroelastic tissue between the rings.
  • Epithelium: Lined with transitional epithelium, which forms many folds when the bladder is in a relaxed state.
  • The bladder wall consists of three smooth muscle layers – inner longitudinal, outer circular, and outermost longitudinal, known collectively as the detrusor muscle.
  • These layers of smooth muscle and elastic fibers contract during micturition.
  • Muscularis Mucosa: Separate the lamina propria from the submucosa, but it is often incomplete and not always visible.
  • Adventitia: The outer adventitial coat contains arteries, veins, and lymphatic vessels.
   

Stomach (Option A & C): The stomach is lined by simple columnar epithelium with gastric pits and glands, including surface mucous cells, mucous neck cells, parietal cells, and chief cells. It would not typically show the features of the urinary bladder or trachea

.

Fig. Histology of stomach

Lymph node (Option A & C): A lymph node features a capsule, cortex with lymphatic follicles, and a medulla with medullary cords and sinuses. It does not match the typical histological features of the trachea or urinary bladder.


Fig. Histology of lymph node

questions.text: Which of the following structures is characterized by the presence of compound tubuloalveolar mucous glands in the submucosa, and a muscular layer that transitions from skeletal to smooth muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Esophagus

 

Explanation:

The esophagus is lined with nonkeratinized stratified squamous epithelium and contains mucous glands (esophageal glands proper) in its submucosa for lubrication. Its muscular layer transitions from skeletal muscle (upper third) to smooth muscle (lower third), characteristic of the process of swallowing.

Structure

Description

Esophagus

 
  • Has four layers: mucosa, submucosa, muscularis externa, and adventitia.
  • Lumen lined with nonkeratinized stratified squamous epithelium.
  • Submucosa- compound tubuloalveolar mucous glands, known as esophageal glands proper, which aid in lubrication.
  • The upper third of the esophagus has predominantly skeletal muscle due to voluntary control during swallowing.
  • In the middle third, there is a gradual transition to smooth muscle, and the lower third consists entirely of smooth muscle.
  • Lacks a serous covering, except for a short section near its lower end.

Stomach (Option B ruled out)
  • The epithelium-forming glands are supported by Lamina Propria, a connective tissue.
  • It has a peritoneum called serosa, which is missing from the oesophagus.
  • Lined by Simple columnar epithelium and forms some gastric glands
  • Mucosa contains gastric pits or gastric foveolae.
  • The gastric glands contain:
    • Surface mucous cells- Bicarbonate ions
    • Mucous neck cells- mucus
    • Parietal (Oxyntic) cells- HCL & Intrinsic Factor.
    • Chief, peptic or zymogenic cells- Pepsin
    • Neuroendocrine cells- Serotonin & Gastrin hormone.

Small Intestine (Option C & D ruled out)

 
  • Small intestine has columnar epithelium, which has villi, and microvilli leading to formation of brush border epithelium.
  • The intestinal villi are lined by a simple columnar epithelium which is continuous with the crypts.
  • Plicae circulares (Valves of Kerckring) are circular folds given by the mucosa and submucosa.
  • Microvilli are finger-like projections to increase the surface area for absorption.
  • Lymphoid clusters called Peyer’s patches are characteristically found in the lamina propria of the small intestine.
  • Cells in the mucosa are:
    • Enterocytes
    • Paneth cells- defence
    • Goblet cells- Mucin
    • Neuroendocrine cells- hormones
